Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Harpokrates seated on the ground with legs extending to his left. He has a long feminine tunic and wears a wreath with lotus buds rising above it and flanking a Double Crown. His finger is to his mouth and he carries an ornate cornucopia in the crook of his left arm. Summary treatment at the rear and underneath: there is no plinth. His large phallus, emerging from below his garment, is shown most clearly on the underside: his left foot is placed on the glans. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a darker brown surface. Traces of a white dressing on the front.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Ptolemaic, probably third to second century BC. Comparanda: Close: Breccia 1934: pl. xxxi: 148 and 150. Near dress and pose of Bayer-Niemeier 1988: nos 68 and 69, seated on a lotus, dated second half of second century AD. Near: Nauerth 1996: pl. iv, fig. 29, from el-Hibeh (Teudjoi; Ankyronpolis) in Middle Egypt.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3048)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Rev Greville John Chester
